drupalNodeEvent.title: Interactions Between African Migrant Workers and Law Enforcement in China

field_speakers.processed: Dr. Roberto Castillo (Cultural Studies Professor at Lingnan University in Hong Kong), Dr. Aaron Tesfaye (Professor and Chair of the Department of Political Science, Legal Studies, and Urban Studies at William Paterson University of New Jersey), and Dr. Guangzhi Huang (Assistant Professor of Interdisciplinary Studies at the Massachusetts College of Liberal Arts)

field_organizers.processed: The Society for Chinese Law and Black Voices on Greater China at Columbia Law School

field_description.processed: Extensive engagement between China and African countries has produced vast exchanges in goods and personnel over the decades. In 2012, it was estimated that more than 100,000 Africans lived in the southern city of Guangzhou, China. Nevertheless, Black communities in China have long reported inconsistent immigration law enforcement and racial profiling, an issue that has come under the spotlight since the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic. Recent months saw increased reports of random passport inspections, incidents of housing discrimination, and arbitrary detainment. In response, the Chinese government claims to be addressing illegal entry of foreigners and “imported” cases of Covid-19. Such incidents have drawn the attention of commentators across the globe to the treatment of African migrant workers by law enforcement. This panel will explore how China’s work visa policies impact African workers currently in or hoping to enter China in today's context.
